docs.title: Installation
docs.text: pip install opendal

docs.title: Local Usage
docs.text:
Developer must set two required arguments to work with files locally: - scheme: which should be specified as fs - root: where OpenDAl considers the root of the directory for operations will be.

For example in the following operator: opendal.Operator("fs", root="/foo")

OpenDAL considers /foo to be the root of all paths, and that means that we can access paths inside of /foo without specifying anything else. If /foo happens to contain the file baz.txt, we can simply call .list("/")

We can see this in the following example:

from opendal import Operator
from pathlib import Path
import os


os.makedirs("foo", exist_ok=True)

file = Path("foo", "bar.txt")
file.touch()

op = Operator("fs", root=Path("foo").name)
for file in op.list("/"):
    print(file)

When running we get the following output:

/
bar.txt

If we want full access to our file system, we can specify a root of "/", but note that for any operations you will always need to specify the full path to a file or directory.

docs.title: Reading
docs.text:
There are two ways to read data using OpenDAL. One way is to use the read method on an operator: 

from opendal import Operator
from pathlib import Path
import os


os.makedirs("foo", exist_ok=True)

file = Path("foo", "bar.txt")
file.touch()
file.write_text("baz")


op = Operator("fs", root=Path("foo").name)

data = op.read(file.name)
print(data)

Yields the following: 

b'baz'

Note that the output is bytes, but we can get it as a string by simply calling .decode() on the data we read. All reads with OpenDAL return bytes.

Now lets use the open method on an operator: 

from opendal import Operator
from pathlib import Path
import os


os.makedirs("foo", exist_ok=True)

file = Path("foo", "bar.txt")
file.touch()
file.write_text("baz")


op = Operator("fs", root=Path("foo").name)

with op.open(file.name, "rb") as f:
    print(f.read())

This again yields 

b'baz'

Again, note that all reads with OpenDAL return bytes, so specifying a mode of "r" will raise an exception.

docs.title: Writing
docs.text:
Now that we know how to read data, let's replace the Pathlib code above with OpenDAL using the write method: 

from opendal import Operator
from pathlib import Path


op = Operator("fs", root=Path("foo").name)

op.write("baz.txt", "my amazing data".encode())

print(op.read("baz.txt").decode())

This yields the following: 

my amazing data

And again, but using the open method: 

from opendal import Operator
from pathlib import Path


op = Operator("fs", root=Path("foo").name)

with op.open("baz.txt", "wb") as f:
    f.write("my amazing data".encode())

print(op.read("baz.txt").decode())

This again yields:

my amazing data

Again, note that all writing happens in bytes and a mode of "w" will raise an exception.

docs.title: Async
docs.text:
OpenDAL supports async operation on all operator methods. One can simply replace the Operator with an AsyncOperator and await on method calls. The below example illustrates this behavior:

Standard API:

import opendal

op = opendal.Operator("fs", root="/tmp")
op.write("test.txt", b"Hello World")
print(op.read("test.txt"))
print(op.stat("test.txt").content_length)

Async API equivalent:

import asyncio

async def main():
    op = opendal.AsyncOperator("fs", root="/tmp")
    await op.write("test.txt", b"Hello World")
    print(await op.read("test.txt"))

asyncio.run(main())

docs.title: AsyncFile
docs.text:
An async file-like object for reading and writing data.

Created by the open method of the AsyncOperator class.

docs.title: closed property
docs.text: Whether this file is closed.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns True if this file is closed.

docs.title: close()
docs.text:
Close this file.

This also flushes write buffers, if applicable.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: A closed file cannot be used for further I/O operations.

docs.title: read(size=None)
docs.text:
Read at most size bytes from this file asynchronously.

If size is not specified, read until EOF.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: size : int, optional The maximum number of bytes to read.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns the bytes read from the stream.

docs.title: readable()
docs.text: Whether this file can be read from.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns True if this file can be read from.

docs.title: seek(pos, whence=0)
docs.text: Change the position of this file to the given byte offset.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: pos : int The byte offset (position) to set. whence : int, optional The reference point for the offset. 0: start of file (default); 1: current position; 2: end of file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns the current absolute position.

docs.title: seekable()
docs.text: Whether this file can be repositioned.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: This is only applicable to readable files.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns True if this file can be repositioned.

docs.title: tell()
docs.text: Return the current position of this file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns the current absolute position.

docs.title: writable()
docs.text: Whether this file can be written to.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns True if this file can be written to.

docs.title: write(bs)
docs.text: Write bytes to this file asynchronously.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: bs : bytes The bytes to write to the file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns the number of bytes written.

docs.title: AsyncOperator
docs.text:
The async equivalent of Operator.

AsyncOperator is the entry point for all async APIs.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text: Operator

docs.title: __new__(scheme, **kwargs)
docs.text: Create a new AsyncOperator.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: scheme : str The scheme of the service. **kwargs : dict The options for the service.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: AsyncOperator The new async operator.

docs.title: capability()
docs.text: Get all capabilities of this operator.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: Capability The capability of the operator.

docs.title: check()
docs.text: Check if the operator is able to work correctly.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that completes when the check is finished.

docs.title: Raises
docs.text: Exception If the operator is not able to work correctly.

docs.title: copy(source, target)
docs.text: Copy a file from one path to another.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: source : str The path to the source file. target : str The path to the target file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that completes when the copy is finished.

docs.title: create_dir(path)
docs.text: Create a directory at the given path.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: To indicate that a path is a directory, it must end with a /. This operation is always recursive, like mkdir -p.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the directory.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that completes when the directory is created.

docs.title: delete(path)
docs.text: Delete a file at the given path.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: This operation will not return an error if the path does not exist.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that completes when the file is deleted.

docs.title: exists(path)
docs.text: Check if a path exists.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to check.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns True if the path exists, False otherwise.

docs.title: layer(layer)
docs.text: Add a new layer to the operator.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: layer : Layer The layer to add.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: AsyncOperator A new operator with the layer added.

docs.title: list(path, *, limit=None, start_after=None, recursive=None, versions=None, deleted=None)
docs.text: List entries in the given directory.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the directory. limit : int, optional The maximum number of entries to return. start_after : str, optional The entry to start after. recursive : bool, optional Whether to list recursively. versions : bool, optional Whether to list versions. deleted : bool, optional Whether to list deleted entries.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns an async iterator over the entries.

docs.title: open(path, mode, **kwargs)
docs.text:
Open an async file-like object for the given path.

The returning async file-like object is a context manager.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the file. mode : str The mode to open the file in. Only "rb" and "wb" are supported. **kwargs : dict Additional options for the underlying reader or writer.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns a file-like object.

docs.title: presign_delete(path, expire_second)
docs.text: Create a presigned request for a delete operation.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path of the object to delete. expire_second : int The number of seconds until the presigned URL expires.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns a presigned request object.

docs.title: presign_read(path, expire_second)
docs.text: Create a presigned request for a read operation.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path of the object to read. expire_second : int The number of seconds until the presigned URL expires.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns a presigned request object.

docs.title: presign_stat(path, expire_second)
docs.text: Create a presigned request for a stat operation.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path of the object to stat. expire_second : int The number of seconds until the presigned URL expires.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns a presigned request object.

docs.title: presign_write(path, expire_second)
docs.text: Create a presigned request for a write operation.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path of the object to write to. expire_second : int The number of seconds until the presigned URL expires.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns a presigned request object.

docs.title: read(path, *, version=None, concurrent=None, chunk=None, gap=None, offset=None, prefetch=None, size=None, if_match=None, if_none_match=None, if_modified_since=None, if_unmodified_since=None, content_type=None, cache_control=None, content_disposition=None)
docs.text: Read the entire contents of a file at the given path.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the file. version : str, optional The version of the file. concurrent : int, optional The number of concurrent readers. chunk : int, optional The size of each chunk. gap : int, optional The gap between each chunk. offset : int, optional The offset of the file. prefetch : int, optional The number of bytes to prefetch. size : int, optional The size of the file. if_match : str, optional The ETag of the file. if_none_match : str, optional The ETag of the file. if_modified_since : str, optional The last modified time of the file. if_unmodified_since : str, optional The last modified time of the file. content_type : str, optional The content type of the file. cache_control : str, optional The cache control of the file. content_disposition : str, optional The content disposition of the file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns the contents of the file as bytes.

docs.title: remove_all(path)
docs.text: Recursively remove all files and directories at the given path.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to remove.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that completes when the removal is finished.

docs.title: rename(source, target)
docs.text: Rename (move) a file from one path to another.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: source : str The path to the source file. target : str The path to the target file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that completes when the rename is finished.

docs.title: stat(path, *, version=None, if_match=None, if_none_match=None, if_modified_since=None, if_unmodified_since=None, content_type=None, cache_control=None, content_disposition=None)
docs.text: Get the metadata of a file at the given path.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the file. version : str, optional The version of the file. if_match : str, optional The ETag of the file. if_none_match : str, optional The ETag of the file. if_modified_since : datetime, optional The last modified time of the file. if_unmodified_since : datetime, optional The last modified time of the file. content_type : str, optional The content type of the file. cache_control : str, optional The cache control of the file. content_disposition : str, optional The content disposition of the file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that returns the metadata of the file.

docs.title: to_operator()
docs.text: Create a new blocking Operator from this async operator.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: Operator The blocking operator.

docs.title: write(path, bs, *, append=None, chunk=None, concurrent=None, cache_control=None, content_type=None, content_disposition=None, content_encoding=None, if_match=None, if_none_match=None, if_not_exists=None, user_metadata=None)
docs.text:
Write bytes to a file at the given path.

This function will create a file if it does not exist, and will overwrite its contents if it does.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the file. bs : bytes The contents to write to the file. append : bool, optional Whether to append to the file instead of overwriting it. chunk : int, optional The chunk size to use when writing the file. concurrent : int, optional The number of concurrent requests to make when writing the file. cache_control : str, optional The cache control header to set on the file. content_type : str, optional The content type header to set on the file. content_disposition : str, optional The content disposition header to set on the file. content_encoding : str, optional The content encoding header to set on the file. if_match : str, optional The ETag to match when writing the file. if_none_match : str, optional The ETag to not match when writing the file. if_not_exists : bool, optional Whether to fail if the file already exists. user_metadata : dict, optional The user metadata to set on the file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: coroutine An awaitable that completes when the write is finished.

docs.title: Capability
docs.text:
Capability defines the supported operations and their constraints for an Operator.

This structure provides a comprehensive description of an Operator's capabilities, including:

  • Basic operations support (read, write, delete, etc.)
  • Advanced operation variants (conditional operations, metadata handling)
  • Operational constraints (size limits, batch limitations)

docs.title: copy property
docs.text: If operator supports copy.

docs.title: create_dir property
docs.text: If operator supports create dir.

docs.title: delete property
docs.text: If operator supports delete.

docs.title: list property
docs.text: If operator supports list.

docs.title: list_with_limit property
docs.text: If backend supports list with limit.

docs.title: list_with_recursive property
docs.text: If backend supports list without delimiter.

docs.title: list_with_start_after property
docs.text: If backend supports list with start after.

docs.title: presign property
docs.text: If operator supports presign.

docs.title: presign_delete property
docs.text: If operator supports presign delete.

docs.title: presign_read property
docs.text: If operator supports presign read.

docs.title: presign_stat property
docs.text: If operator supports presign stat.

docs.title: presign_write property
docs.text: If operator supports presign write.

docs.title: read property
docs.text: If the operator supports read operations.

docs.title: read_with_if_match property
docs.text: If conditional read operations using If-Match are supported.

docs.title: read_with_if_modified_since property
docs.text: If conditional read operations using If-Modified-Since are supported.

docs.title: read_with_if_none_match property
docs.text: If conditional read operations using If-None-Match are supported.

docs.title: read_with_if_unmodified_since property
docs.text: If conditional read operations using If-Unmodified-Since are supported.

docs.title: read_with_override_cache_control property
docs.text: If Cache-Control header override is supported during read operations.

docs.title: read_with_override_content_disposition property
docs.text: If Content-Disposition header can be overridden during read operations.

docs.title: read_with_override_content_type property
docs.text: If Content-Type header override is supported during read operations.

docs.title: read_with_version property
docs.text: If versions read operations are supported.

docs.title: rename property
docs.text: If operator supports rename.

docs.title: shared property
docs.text: If operator supports shared.

docs.title: stat property
docs.text: If operator supports stat.

docs.title: stat_with_if_match property
docs.text: If operator supports stat with if match.

docs.title: stat_with_if_none_match property
docs.text: If operator supports stat with if none match.

docs.title: write property
docs.text: If the operator supports write operations.

docs.title: write_can_append property
docs.text: If append operations are supported.

docs.title: write_can_empty property
docs.text: If writing empty content is supported.

docs.title: write_can_multi property
docs.text: If multiple write operations can be performed on the same object.

docs.title: write_multi_max_size property
docs.text:
Maximum size supported for multipart uploads.

For example, AWS S3 supports up to 5GiB per part in multipart uploads.

docs.title: write_multi_min_size property
docs.text:
Minimum size required for multipart uploads (except for the last part).

For example, AWS S3 requires at least 5MiB per part.

docs.title: write_total_max_size property
docs.text:
Maximum total size supported for write operations.

For example, Cloudflare D1 has a 1MB total size limit.

docs.title: write_with_cache_control property
docs.text: If Cache-Control can be specified during write operations.

docs.title: write_with_content_disposition property
docs.text: If Content-Disposition can be specified during write operations.

docs.title: write_with_content_encoding property
docs.text: If Content-Encoding can be specified during write operations.

docs.title: write_with_content_type property
docs.text: If Content-Type can be specified during write operations.

docs.title: write_with_if_match property
docs.text: If conditional write operations using If-Match are supported.

docs.title: write_with_if_none_match property
docs.text: If conditional write operations using If-None-Match are supported.

docs.title: write_with_if_not_exists property
docs.text: If write operations can be conditional on object non-existence.

docs.title: write_with_user_metadata property
docs.text: If custom user metadata can be attached during write operations.

docs.title: Exceptions
docs.text:
This page documents all exceptions raised by the OpenDAL.

Bases: Exception

OpenDAL Base Exception.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class Error(builtins.Exception):
    r"""OpenDAL Base Exception."""

Bases: Exception

Already exists.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class AlreadyExists(builtins.Exception):
    r"""Already exists."""

Bases: Exception

Condition not match.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class ConditionNotMatch(builtins.Exception):
    r"""Condition not match."""

Bases: Exception

Config is invalid.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class ConfigInvalid(builtins.Exception):
    r"""Config is invalid."""

Bases: Exception

Is a directory.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class IsADirectory(builtins.Exception):
    r"""Is a directory."""

Bases: Exception

Is same file.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class IsSameFile(builtins.Exception):
    r"""Is same file."""

Bases: Exception

Not a directory.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class NotADirectory(builtins.Exception):
    r"""Not a directory."""

Bases: Exception

Not found.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class NotFound(builtins.Exception):
    r"""Not found."""

Bases: Exception

Permission denied.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class PermissionDenied(builtins.Exception):
    r"""Permission denied."""

Bases: Exception

Unexpected errors.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class Unexpected(builtins.Exception):
    r"""Unexpected errors."""

Bases: Exception

Unsupported operation.

Source code in python/opendal/exceptions.pyi 
class Unsupported(builtins.Exception):
    r"""Unsupported operation."""

docs.title: File
docs.text:
A file-like object for reading and writing data.

Created by the open method of the Operator class.

docs.title: closed property
docs.text: Whether this file is closed.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: bool True if this file is closed.

docs.title: close()
docs.text:
Close this file.

This also flushes write buffers, if applicable.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: A closed file cannot be used for further I/O operations.

docs.title: flush()
docs.text: Flush the underlying writer.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: Is a no-op if the file is not writable.

docs.title: read(size=None)
docs.text:
Read at most size bytes from this file.

If size is not specified, read until EOF.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: size : int, optional The maximum number of bytes to read.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: bytes The bytes read from this file.

docs.title: readable()
docs.text: Whether this file can be read from.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: bool True if this file can be read from.

docs.title: readinto(buffer)
docs.text: Read bytes into a pre-allocated buffer.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: buffer : bytes | bytearray A writable, pre-allocated buffer to read into.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: int The number of bytes read.

docs.title: readline(size=None)
docs.text:
Read one line from this file.

If size is not specified, read until newline.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: size : int, optional The maximum number of bytes to read.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: Retains newline characters after each line, unless the file’s last line has no terminating newline.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: bytes The bytes read from this file.

docs.title: seek(pos, whence=0)
docs.text: Change the position of this file to the given byte offset.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: pos : int The byte offset (position) to set. whence : int, optional The reference point for the offset. 0: start of file (default); 1: current position; 2: end of file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: int The new absolute position.

docs.title: seekable()
docs.text: Whether this file can be repositioned.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: This is only applicable to readable files.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: bool True if this file can be repositioned.

docs.title: tell()
docs.text: Return the current position of this file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: int The current absolute position.

docs.title: writable()
docs.text: Whether this file can be written to.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: bool True if this file can be written to.

docs.title: write(bs)
docs.text: Write bytes to this file.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: bs : bytes The bytes to write to the file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: int The number of bytes written.

docs.title: Layers
docs.text: This page documents all layers in OpenDAL.

docs.title: Layer
docs.text: Layers are used to intercept the operations on the underlying storage.

docs.title: RetryLayer
docs.text:
Bases: Layer

A layer that retries operations that fail with temporary errors.

Operations are retried if they fail with an error for which Error.is_temporary returns True. If all retries are exhausted, the error is marked as persistent and then returned.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: After an operation on a Reader or Writer has failed through all retries, the object is in an undefined state. Reusing it can lead to exceptions.

docs.title: __new__(max_times=None, factor=None, jitter=False, max_delay=None, min_delay=None)
docs.text: Create a new RetryLayer.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: max_times : Optional[int] Maximum number of retry attempts. Defaults to 3. factor : Optional[float] Backoff factor applied between retries. Defaults to 2.0. jitter : bool Whether to apply jitter to the backoff. Defaults to False. max_delay : Optional[float] Maximum delay (in seconds) between retries. Defaults to 60.0. min_delay : Optional[float] Minimum delay (in seconds) between retries. Defaults to 1.0.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: RetryLayer

docs.title: ConcurrentLimitLayer
docs.text:
Bases: Layer

A layer that limits the number of concurrent operations.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: All operators wrapped by this layer will share a common semaphore. This allows you to reuse the same layer across multiple operators, ensuring that the total number of concurrent requests across the entire application does not exceed the limit.

docs.title: __new__(limit)
docs.text: Create a new ConcurrentLimitLayer.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: limit : int Maximum number of concurrent operations allowed.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: ConcurrentLimitLayer

docs.title: MimeGuessLayer
docs.text:
Bases: Layer

A layer that guesses MIME types for objects based on their paths or content.

This layer uses the mime_guess crate (see https://crates.io/crates/mime_guess) to infer the Content-Type.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
This layer will not override a Content-Type that has already been set, either manually or by the backend service. It is only applied if no content type is present.

A Content-Type is not guaranteed. If the file extension is uncommon or unknown, the content type will remain unset.

docs.title: __new__()
docs.text: Create a new MimeGuessLayer.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: MimeGuessLayer

docs.text:
The blocking equivalent of AsyncOperator.

Operator is the entry point for all blocking APIs.

docs.title: create_dir(path)

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: To indicate that a path is a directory, it must end with a /. This operation is always recursive, like mkdir -p.

docs.text: Delete a file at the given path.

docs.title: Notes

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to check.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: bool True if the path exists, False otherwise.

docs.title: layer(layer)
docs.text: Add a new layer to this operator.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: layer : Layer The layer to add.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: Operator A new operator with the layer added.

docs.title: list(path, *, limit=None, start_after=None, recursive=None, versions=None, deleted=None)
docs.text: List entries in the given directory.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the directory. limit : int, optional The maximum number of entries to return. start_after : str, optional The entry to start after. recursive : bool, optional Whether to list recursively. versions : bool, optional Whether to list versions. deleted : bool, optional Whether to list deleted entries.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: BlockingLister An iterator over the entries in the directory.

docs.title: open(path, mode, **kwargs)
docs.text:
Open a file-like object for the given path.

The returning file-like object is a context manager.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the file. mode : str The mode to open the file in. Only "rb" and "wb" are supported. **kwargs Additional options for the underlying reader or writer.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: File A file-like object.

docs.title: read(path, *, version=None, concurrent=None, chunk=None, gap=None, offset=None, prefetch=None, size=None, if_match=None, if_none_match=None, if_modified_since=None, if_unmodified_since=None, content_type=None, cache_control=None, content_disposition=None)
docs.text: Read the entire contents of a file at the given path.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the file. version : str, optional The version of the file. concurrent : int, optional The number of concurrent readers. chunk : int, optional The size of each chunk. gap : int, optional The gap between each chunk. offset : int, optional The offset of the file. prefetch : int, optional The number of bytes to prefetch. size : int, optional The size of the file. if_match : str, optional The ETag of the file. if_none_match : str, optional The ETag of the file. if_modified_since : str, optional The last modified time of the file. if_unmodified_since : str, optional The last modified time of the file. content_type : str, optional The content type of the file. cache_control : str, optional The cache control of the file. content_disposition : str, optional The content disposition of the file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: bytes The contents of the file as bytes.

docs.title: remove_all(path)
docs.text: Recursively remove all files and directories at the given path.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to remove.

docs.title: rename(source, target)
docs.text: Rename (move) a file from one path to another.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: source : str The path to the source file. target : str The path to the target file.

docs.title: scan(path, *, limit=None, start_after=None, versions=None, deleted=None)
docs.text: Recursively list entries in the given directory.

docs.title: Deprecated
docs.text: Use `list()` with `recursive=True` instead.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the directory. limit : int, optional The maximum number of entries to return. start_after : str, optional The entry to start after. versions : bool, optional Whether to list versions. deleted : bool, optional Whether to list deleted entries.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: BlockingLister An iterator over the entries in the directory.

docs.title: stat(path, *, version=None, if_match=None, if_none_match=None, if_modified_since=None, if_unmodified_since=None, content_type=None, cache_control=None, content_disposition=None)
docs.text: Get the metadata of a file at the given path.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the file. version : str, optional The version of the file. if_match : str, optional The ETag of the file. if_none_match : str, optional The ETag of the file. if_modified_since : datetime, optional The last modified time of the file. if_unmodified_since : datetime, optional The last modified time of the file. content_type : str, optional The content type of the file. cache_control : str, optional The cache control of the file. content_disposition : str, optional The content disposition of the file.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: Metadata The metadata of the file.

docs.title: to_async_operator()
docs.text: Create a new AsyncOperator from this blocking operator.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: AsyncOperator The async operator.

docs.title: write(path, bs, *, append=None, chunk=None, concurrent=None, cache_control=None, content_type=None, content_disposition=None, content_encoding=None, if_match=None, if_none_match=None, if_not_exists=None, user_metadata=None)
docs.text:
Write bytes to a file at the given path.

This function will create a file if it does not exist, and will overwrite its contents if it does.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: path : str The path to the file. bs : bytes The contents to write to the file. append : bool, optional Whether to append to the file instead of overwriting it. chunk : int, optional The chunk size to use when writing the file. concurrent : int, optional The number of concurrent requests to make when writing the file. cache_control : str, optional The cache control header to set on the file. content_type : str, optional The content type header to set on the file. content_disposition : str, optional The content disposition header to set on the file. content_encoding : str, optional The content encoding header to set on the file. if_match : str, optional The ETag to match when writing the file. if_none_match : str, optional The ETag to not match when writing the file. if_not_exists : bool, optional Whether to fail if the file already exists. user_metadata : dict, optional The user metadata to set on the file.

docs.title: Types
docs.text: This page documents all types in OpenDAL.

docs.title: Entry
docs.text:
Entry.

An entry representing a path and its associated metadata.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: If this entry is a directory, path must end with /. Otherwise, path must not end with /.

docs.title: metadata property
docs.text: The metadata of this entry.

docs.title: name property
docs.text: The name of entry, representing the last segment of the path.

docs.title: path property
docs.text: The path of entry relative to the operator's root.

docs.title: EntryMode
docs.text:
Bases: Enum

EntryMode.

The mode of an entry, indicating if it is a file or a directory.

Source code in python/opendal/types.pyi 
@typing.final
class EntryMode(enum.Enum):
    r"""
    EntryMode.

    The mode of an entry, indicating if it is a file or a directory.
    """

    File = ...
    r"""
    The entry is a file and has data to read.
    """
    Dir = ...
    r"""
    The entry is a directory and can be listed.
    """
    Unknown = ...
    r"""
    The mode of the entry is unknown.
    """

    def is_file(self) -> builtins.bool:
        r"""
        Check if the entry mode is `File`.

        Returns
        -------
        bool
            True if the entry is a file.
        """
    def is_dir(self) -> builtins.bool:
        r"""
        Check if the entry mode is `Dir`.

        Returns
        -------
        bool
            True if the entry is a directory.
        """

docs.title: Dir = ... class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: The entry is a directory and can be listed.

docs.title: File = ... class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: The entry is a file and has data to read.

docs.title: Unknown = ... class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: The mode of the entry is unknown.

docs.title: is_dir()
docs.text: Check if the entry mode is Dir.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
bool True if the entry is a directory.

Source code in python/opendal/types.pyi 
def is_dir(self) -> builtins.bool:
    r"""
    Check if the entry mode is `Dir`.

    Returns
    -------
    bool
        True if the entry is a directory.
    """

docs.title: is_file()
docs.text: Check if the entry mode is File.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
bool True if the entry is a file.

Source code in python/opendal/types.pyi 
def is_file(self) -> builtins.bool:
    r"""
    Check if the entry mode is `File`.

    Returns
    -------
    bool
        True if the entry is a file.
    """

docs.title: Metadata
docs.text:
The metadata of an Entry.

The metadata is always tied to a specific context and is not a global state. For example, two versions of the same path might have different content lengths.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: In systems that support versioning, such as AWS S3, the metadata may represent a specific version of a file. Use :attr:version to get the version of a file if it is available.

docs.title: content_disposition property
docs.text: The content disposition of this entry.

docs.title: content_encoding property
docs.text: The content encoding of this entry.

docs.title: content_length property
docs.text: The content length of this entry.

docs.title: content_md5 property
docs.text: The content MD5 of this entry.

docs.title: content_type property
docs.text: The content type of this entry.

docs.title: etag property
docs.text: The ETag of this entry.

docs.title: is_dir property
docs.text: Whether this entry is a directory.

docs.title: is_file property
docs.text: Whether this entry is a file.

docs.title: last_modified property
docs.text: The last modified timestamp of this entry.

docs.title: mode property
docs.text: The mode of this entry.

docs.title: user_metadata property
docs.text: The user-defined metadata of this entry.

docs.title: version property
docs.text: The version of this entry.

docs.title: PresignedRequest
docs.text:
A presigned request.

This contains the information required to make a request to the underlying service, including the URL, method, and headers.

docs.title: headers property
docs.text: The HTTP headers of this request.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: dict The HTTP headers of this request.

docs.title: method property
docs.text: The HTTP method of this request.

docs.title: url property
docs.text: The URL of this request.

docs.title: Basic
docs.text:
In [ ]: Copied! 
# Install the opendal
!pip install opendal
# Install the opendal !pip install opendal In [ ]: Copied! 
import opendal

# Init an operator.
op = opendal.Operator("fs", root="/tmp")
print(f"operator: {op}")

# Write data into object test.
op.write("test", b"Hello, World!")

# Read data from object
bs = op.read("test")
print(f"content: {bs.decode()}")

# Get object metadata.
meta = op.stat("test")
print(f"metadata: {meta}")
import opendal # Init an operator. op = opendal.Operator("fs", root="/tmp") print(f"operator: {op}") # Write data into object test. op.write("test", b"Hello, World!") # Read data from object bs = op.read("test") print(f"content: {bs.decode()}") # Get object metadata. meta = op.stat("test") print(f"metadata: {meta}")

docs.title: Pandas
docs.text:
In [ ]: Copied! 
# Install the opendal and pandas
!pip install opendal, pandas
# Install the opendal and pandas !pip install opendal, pandas In [ ]: Copied! 
import pandas as pd

import opendal

# Init an operator.
op = opendal.Operator("fs", root="/tmp")

# Create and write a csv file
op.write("test.csv", b"name,age\nAlice,25\nBob,30\nCharlie,35")

# Open and read the DataFrame from the file.
with op.open("test.csv", mode="rb") as file:
    read_df = pd.read_csv(file)
    print(f"read_df: {read_df}")
import pandas as pd import opendal # Init an operator. op = opendal.Operator("fs", root="/tmp") # Create and write a csv file op.write("test.csv", b"name,age\nAlice,25\nBob,30\nCharlie,35") # Open and read the DataFrame from the file. with op.open("test.csv", mode="rb") as file: read_df = pd.read_csv(file) print(f"read_df: {read_df}")

docs.title: Polars
docs.text:
In [ ]: Copied! 
# Install the opendal and polars
!pip install opendal, polars
# Install the opendal and polars !pip install opendal, polars In [ ]: Copied! 
import polars as pl

import opendal

# Init an operator.
op = opendal.Operator("fs", root="/tmp")

# Create a DataFrame.
df = pl.DataFrame({"name": ["Alice", "Bob"], "age": [20, 30]})
print(f"df: {df}")

# Open and write the DataFrame to the file.
with op.open("test.csv", mode="wb") as file:
    df.write_csv(file)

# Open and read the DataFrame from the file.
with op.open("test.csv", mode="rb") as file:
    read_df = pl.read_csv(file)
    print(f"read_df: {read_df}")
import polars as pl import opendal # Init an operator. op = opendal.Operator("fs", root="/tmp") # Create a DataFrame. df = pl.DataFrame({"name": ["Alice", "Bob"], "age": [20, 30]}) print(f"df: {df}") # Open and write the DataFrame to the file. with op.open("test.csv", mode="wb") as file: df.write_csv(file) # Open and read the DataFrame from the file. with op.open("test.csv", mode="rb") as file: read_df = pl.read_csv(file) print(f"read_df: {read_df}")
